name: Queen Latifah
description:
'''Dana Elaine Owens''' (born March 18, 1970), known professionally by her stage name '''Queen Latifah''', is an American rapper, singer, and actress. She has received [[List of awards and nominations received by Queen Latifah|various accolades]], including a [[Grammy Award]], a [[Primetime Emmy Awards|Primetime Emmy Award]], a [[Golden Globe Award]], three [[Screen Actors Guild Awards]], and two [[NAACP Image Awards]], in addition to a nomination for an [[Academy Award]]. In 2006, she became the first hip hop artist to receive a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]].

At age 19, Latifah released her debut album ''[[All Hail the Queen]]'' (1989), featuring the hit single "Ladies First". Her second album ''[[Nature of a Sista']]'' (1991), was produced by Tommy Boy Records. Her third album, ''[[Black Reign (album)|Black Reign]]'' (1993), became the first album by a solo female rapper to receive a gold certification from the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA), and spawned the single "[[U.N.I.T.Y.]]", which was influential in raising awareness of violence against women and the objectification of Black female sexuality. The track reached the [[top 40]] on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], and won a [[Grammy Award]]. Her fourth album ''[[Order in the Court]]'' (1998), was released with [[Motown Records Group|Motown Records]]. She has since released the albums ''[[The Dana Owens Album]]'' (2004), ''[[Trav'lin' Light (Queen Latifah album)|Trav'lin' Light]]'' (2007), and ''[[Persona (Queen Latifah album)|Persona]]'' (2009).

Latifah starred as Khadijah James on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] sitcom ''[[Living Single]]'' from 1993 to 1998 and landed a leading role in the action film ''[[Set It Off (film)|Set It Off]]'' (1996). She created the daytime talk show ''[[The Queen Latifah Show]]'', which ran from 1999 to 2001, and again from 2013 to 2015, in syndication. Her portrayal of Matron "Mama" Morton in the musical film ''[[Chicago (2002 film)|Chicago]]'' (2002) received a nomination for the [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress]]. She has also starred or co-starred in the films ''[[Bringing Down the House (film)|Bringing Down the House]]'' (2003), ''[[Taxi (2004 film)|Taxi]]'' (2004), ''[[Barbershop 2: Back in Business]]'' (2005), ''[[Beauty Shop]]'' (2005), ''[[Last Holiday (2006 film)|Last Holiday]]'' (2006), ''[[Hairspray (2007 film)|Hairspray]]'' (2007), ''[[Joyful Noise (film)|Joyful Noise]]'' (2012), ''[[22 Jump Street]]'' (2014), and ''[[Girls Trip]]'' (2017); and provided voice work in the ''[[Ice Age (franchise)|Ice Age]]'' film series.

Latifah received critical acclaim for her portrayal of blues singer [[Bessie Smith]] in the [[HBO]] film ''[[Bessie (film)|Bessie]]'' (2015), which she co-produced, winning the [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Television Movie]]. From 2016 to 2019, she starred as Carlotta Brown in the musical drama series ''[[Star (TV series)|Star]]''. In 2020, she portrayed [[Hattie McDaniel]] in the miniseries ''[[Hollywood (miniseries)|Hollywood]]''. She portrayed the lead role on [[CBS]]'s revival of the action drama ''[[The Equalizer (2021 TV series)|The Equalizer]]'', which aired five seasons from 2021 through 2025.
